replies.text:
Full chapter translation:
"The big Yardratian is their Elder, Pibara. He’s the one that thought Goku IT.
Yardratians are grateful to Goku and Vegeta for finishing off the Ginyu Force before they were attacked.
The Yardratians use “Spirit” and is described (not clearly mentioned/explained fully in the manga chapter) as being either different than Ki or a different way of using Ki (unclear translation for now). Yardratians can harness Spirit to perform instant transmission, duplicate themselves, and greatly increase their size. Vegeta asks them to teach it to him.
Piccolo’s trying to contact the Namekians on New Namek through telepathy but there’s no response.
Dende thinks that their telepathy might just not be that strong but Piccolo says that he feels something bad happening through space and believes it might be because there’s actually nobody there to respond in the first place.
Bulma wanted to tell Dende about Jaco’s call and request help, so she went there.
Upon being defeated by Piccolo, the Macareni Siblings managed to send a distress signal to Moro's crew. Moro said that if those 3 got killed it means the locals of said planet must be quite strong. He orders additional research on the distress call’s origin and if it happens to be a quality planet he'll go personally there to absorb the planet.
Merus knew about UI all along. He tells Goku that’s it’s the exact opposite of SSJ, which is triggered by anger. UI is triggered when you manage to gain control over the impulse brought by shaking emotions.
Merus takes Goku to the Galactic Patrol’s ROSAT.One day outside = three inside. Also, Merus says that it’s completely shut off from the outside world so people on the outside have no idea of what transpires inside there.
Merus teases Goku that because of that he can show him his true strength without any concerns, and promises that he’ll go hard on the Saiyan."

They said, they might make another manga that would be a proper sequel this time which moves the original plot forward. And there were 2 small special chapters a few months ago, so the series hasn't been completely buried yet.

It also had four anime seasons.

After Franxx it's a matter if they want to be like Rumiko and continue despite ridiculous success or Togashi and just say fuck it and laze around. Doubt they ever go weekly again now that Yabuki's married again though.

replies.text:
>>193390620
As a Koharuchad here's what I like about her:
> cute relatively simple design
> great mini arc in season 1 about her growth as a person, one of the few who weren't gunning for an S4 position the whole year
> thrown into sink or swim moments that were 100% embarrassment fuel but she made the best of it and over time, gave her the confidence to be more outgoing
> great friendship with Yume with lots of emotional and memorable moments during the shows run
> the group mediator, she was the one who kept Yume grounded while they were in school together and was the one who helped Mahiru and Ako chill out when they were initially very hostile in the beginning
> great singing voice, albeit rarely utilized
> cute shipping moments with Asahi which sadly was left without a resolution
> lots of great in-jokes due to the way she was involved with all the Kasumi siblings
> GOAT PR card in Photokatsu

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
I enjoyed it a lot, but I didn't think it was amazing.

The CG is so close to being great, but it's just shy of getting there. The "limited framerate/no keyframe interpolation" shit is done way better then anything else i've seen... but it's still like that and it still would look better if it didn't. The animation is dynamic and there's a ton of shit moving at any given point... but there's still some static elements of models like people in cockpits that stands out that would be in motion had it been in 2d. On the flip side though I really dug all the almost psychdellic uses of geometric shapes, colors/lights, and negative space. A lot of sections were almost music-video esque.

I also just wish it was longer. I wouldn't say it's rushed but I think it would have benefitted from being like a 3 or 4 part OVA or a series of 12 episodes to really explore the world and characters more (I wanted to see more shit from Lio's perspective, more time for his and Galo's rivarly to build, more shit about Kray's motivitions, what the fuck promare are, etc), allow shit more time to breath and stuff to sink in, and for the action scenes to not be quite as insanely frantic and quick.

Would love to see it a second time to see how much my opinions change but I don't think there's more showings by me.

Also I want to fuck Lio super bad.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Miku is the worst character I've ever seen in this manga. It really pissed me off that such a waifubait, pathetic and cliche ridden character occupied the first spot in the Japanese fan polls conducted. That speaks volumes about her mouthbreathing fanbase rather than anything else, who have really bad taste and have too much time on their hands. I shall attempt to enlighten the Mikufags of the various ways she flat out sucks.

>Bland design
On the whole Miku is ok at best. But when compared to the designs of the other girls in the series she comes dead last. The tired yamato nadeshiko trope is applied to her with her long straight hair and meek personality. Compare Miku with Nino, Itsuki or even Yotsuba. She looks too bland and unoriginal compared to the others. Too plain. Just like a bowl of boiled rice. Grown up Miku looks the worst amongst the quints, with her Takagi type fivehead and weird haircut.

>Boring personality
I know this point has been reiterated several times, but Miku is really boring. Initially she was kind of interesting with her banter with Nino and Fuutarou. She had the guts to face them head on and not cower under the sheets like a baby. But now she comes across as too lame and uninteresting. Like a stale piece of limp celery. Reminds me of Kosaki from nisekoi. I especially hate the way she does absolutely nothing (besides baking some croissants) and expects Fuutarou to magically fall in love with her. And I hate the way she expects the other quints to back off since she had ""dibs"" on Fuutarou just because she fell for him first. But then again Japs and betas love a docile, meek and le gamer girl to satisfy their neckbeard fantasies.

(1/2)

>>193399408
>No ambition
Ichika wants to be an actress, Nino wants to start a restaurant, Yotsuba can be an athlete, Itsuki wants to be a teacher. Now what exactly is Miku's ambition besides lusting after Fuutarou's dick? No clue!! The author tried to shove some hamfisted crap about being a history geek, but honestly that is no use in the real world and is quickly forgotten. Later she tries unsuccessfully to become a baker, which was brought about by pure spite and petty competitiveness against Nino.

>Physical harm to the MC
With the exception of Nino, who drugged Fuutarou twice, Miku has caused Fuutarou to get a stomach ache and a nosebleed from force feeding him poisonous food. None of the others have done anything remotely bad as this to him. At least Nino had the decency to apologize for what she had done.
Now all this would not be a problem if her chances of winning were low or non-existent. But judging from the way the author is setting up the story she seems to be a candidate in the forefront. Also judging from Negi's twitter reaction to the latest chapter he seems desparate to placate her fans which leads me to conclude she could win the Fuutaroubowl. A pity win is the worst possible outcome that an love story could conclude with.

Fuck Miku and her pathetic fanboys.

(2/2)

>>193336194
Blatant misunderstanding of the Code of Hammurabi.
Retributive justice predated the Code of Hammurabi and its tendency to cause feuds was well understood even back then. The Code of Hammurabi contains retributive justice because it arose from a culture where it was the norm but is designed to squelch those sorts of feuds.
Hammurabi's legal system involves a judgement at a trial. If you got taken to court and lost an eye as punishment, but feel that you shouldn't have lost the eye, you can't take anyone else to trial over it. Ypur accusation would get thrown out.
Before Hammurabi if someone broke your arm in what they insisted was retribution, but you felt they had no grounds to, you could and would try to round up a mob and break their arm.

That's hard. The thing about Manga is that sometimes I get bored reading the text and just look at the images and miss key plot points. With LNs, it feels nice to use my imagination and but sometimes it gets hard to get through some of the more boring parts and I lose motivation to keep reading.

So my usual strategy is to read the first 10 or so chapters of the manga adaptation to get a feel for the story + character designs and then if it's good I read the novel. Long story short? A good LN > good manga but a mediocre manga > mediocre LN.

>>193371095
>Both viral
Will you say that pneumonia is viral too?
That sounds very wrong to me while symptoms can be similar usually sore throat or sniffles are caused by bacteria attacking weakened area of mucus membranes in nose and throat e.g. when you dress too lightly or sit under AC etc.
Meaning the pathogens were already present in considerable numbers in your own body as is, it's just they were suppressed by immunity.
You can catch cold (and even pneumonia) from someone else but viruses don't usually arise on their own you've got to get infected furst.

I really, really fucking loved Soul Land 1 which is basically an Isekai.

MC was a genius from a Sect that made hidden weapons, he reincarnates in a world that uses a "spirit" as a weapon, which falls in 2 categories, a "tool" or a "beastification" and they get stronger by absorbing monsters which adds their power to the base spirit. It's honestly a pretty good idea and it's really well done imo on the 1st Soul Land (There are 4 main stories being published and novels are on the 4th).

There are a lot of stupid chink shit and cultivation but it's such a great world that i dont mind some of the lacking parts.

subject: Precure
name: Anonymous
text:
The Pretty Cure Series (プリキュアシリーズ Purikyua Shirīzu), also known as PreCure (プリキュア Purikyua) is a Japanese magical girl anime franchise created by Izumi Todo and produced by Asahi Broadcasting Corporation, Asatsu-DK and Toei Animation. Each series revolves around a group of magical girls known as Pretty Cures who battle against evil forces. Starting in February 2004 with Futari wa Pretty Cure, the franchise has seen many anime series, spanning over 700 episodes to date, as well as spawning movies, manga, toys, and video games. Its most recent iteration, Star Twinkle PreCure, began airing in February 2019 as part of TV Asahi's Sunday morning children's television block. To date, three series have received English adaptations.

Let's engage in Precure discussion, is your oyo the "oyo!" or "oyo..." today?

PRECURE INTERPOL

>>193383815
>Maho Girls Precure NEXT.

25 years have passed since the final battle against Deusmast, aka: 20 years after the reconnecting between the human world and magical world.

Mirai and Riko were the spearheading pioneers of the unity between the 2 worlds, as ambassadors of their respective realms, both worlds have thrived like never before, with science, tech and magic becoming one, literally anything is possible.

A lot has happened since then, With Haa returning to the center of the universe to take full part on her job as a goddess, and Mofurun returning to her original form as a plushie, now 'taking care' of Mirai's daughter, a young and rebellious girl who feels abandoned by her mother, but wont stop at nothing to take down those who harm the weak and innocent.

Riko also got a daughter of her own, your typical prodigy student, always being prudent and peaceful, not the kind of girl who likes to get in fights.

One day, at an event commemorating the 20th anniversary of the realms reconnection, the people was attacked by a group of people, a group who believes chaos should only reign. The casualties were numerous, and the worst of all, Mirai and Riko got captured.

>>193388190
Haa is still working as a goddess, someone else would take her place as Cure Felice.

The idea for the evil organization is a trio of chaos seeking people, who use different skills to create their monsters. one will depend on science, other on tech and Machinery, and the third one, Magic.

the Magic user, is a Fairy from the same Tribe Haa came originally, who believes Mankind and Wizardkind cannot coexist one way or another, and would prefer the world being destroyed. later we will discover, that she was actually kidnapped and brainwashed by the evil group as part of their scheme of using the power of the precure due to her connections to Mother Rapapa/Haa in case it turns out is impossible to use Mofurun for that.

Once the cures manage to release her from the brainwashing, thats the point where Haa would give her the Emerald stone to become the new Cure Felice.

The method the evil group uses to summon their monsters is using extract from the remnants of the Wishing stone, the same one Mofu used in the movie, eventually all the fragments are gathered, and thru the power of their bonds, the wishing stone is reborn, allowing Mofurun to become CureMofu once more.

name: Anonymous
text:
>In the last week, two significant events impacted the global financial market sentiments: drone attacks on Saudi Arabia's oil production facilities and ECB's announcement of introducing a fresh rate cut and restarting quantitative easing. The events prompted downside moves in the global equity market, which, in turn, increased bids in haven assets such as gold and U.S. Treasuries. Bitcoin, on the other hand, appeared like a mum spectator

>Investors picked safe-havens, but they ignored bitcoin. Their decision to fly their capital into more traditional hedging assets benefited gold. The yellow metal surged by as much as 1.6% on the day oil registered a 20% loss. Treasuries advanced as well, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year bond coming down to 1.792%. It is still trending downwards.

>What's further worsening the case for bitcoin is its cryptocurrency community itself. Over the past 48 hours, a large portion of bitcoin capital has shifted to alternative cryptocurrencies. The outflow of some $8 billion has pushed the bitcoin market dominance down to about 67%. On Monday, it was as high as 70.3%, according to data provided by CoinMarketCap.com.

replies.name: Anonymous

>>21385019

The 1UZ weighs about 165kg, the stock engine weighs about 130 or so, maybe a bit less. I've lost weight with a tubular front subframe, and the front core support will be tubular. I'm also using frame rail strengethers and a cross brace underneath.

A 1000kg car with 130hp is really fun, a 1100kg car with 280hp will be really fun. Aside from the cross brace there's no further beefing up needed.

I'm also only really interested in corners, all my most common roads are twisty, straight line speed is fun but lacks longevity, you can always get better at corners.

I didn't say I didn't know anything or have done no research, I just said none of my friends care about cars.

replies.name: James
replies.text:
>>21383199
EIR is an incomprehensible mess that is impossible to summarize in a single post.

I think on two occasions there was serious talk of contacting NASCAR and getting them to investigate the place, which they've done before. I was asked to help out, but nothing materialized as the easier fix was to simply migrate to Castrol Raceway. I'll be trying to embarrass myself in a dirt late model next year if I can sell my car in time.

EIR's core problem is that it's run by a husband and wife duo who by all accounts are just outright bitter, petty people. Their daughter races in the Lucas Oil Sportsman class and her dad basically goes full hockey dad tier if you touch her car, which means races in the highest paying category are semi-fixed. Contact or bump & runs aren't allowed either, so it's a quarter mile oval with the rules of a simdad open wheel road racing league.

I somehow got to officiate for an evening which was hilarious as the track is absolutely awesome if you let people move each other. Think a slightly more banked bowman gray.

If you win a championship in a lower class, you're banned from competing the next season unless you move up to a quicker category. So the main guy running hornets, who built at least 10 different cars and would repair damage on yours for a case of beer, was effectively banned from the track. And it's not like he can just show up with a super late model because amateur racers tend to have wives, a full time job, and multiple children, so a Sunfire is all they can afford to race.

They also banned a sixteen year old kid's entire family, escorted them off the property, and supposedly threatened legal action after he led every lap in a late model race for "reckless driving." This is blowing up on Facebook right now.

Mod race in question that you linked, three cars wrecked at once, guy running about 10 feet behind merely watched them all pile into the wall and was credited with the win.

If someone from an independent racing mag investigated and did an article on it, shit would hit the fan so fast.

subject: CCG / Classic Car General
name: Anonymous
text:
/Classic Car General/
High-waist shorts edition
>Cars are considered "classic" at 25 years old, but a vehicle really needs that certain something to be classic.
>Everybody has their own taste, but some tastes are wrong. If you aren't sure if your car is classic or not, it's not.
>American, European, Japanese, or whatever.
>HOWEVER, your Honda Miata doesn't count as a classic yet. 80s+ Hondas are better suited for their own generals as well. Everything else is fair game.
>Post your classic, your work on it, your hackery, and get advice.
>Any and all discussion about classics welcome, but may not necessarily generate responses; don't get butthurt.
>Period correct performance > cosmetics.
>Metal > plastic.
>Classic shitbox > modern shitbox.
>It's required to use RTV. Ignore the haters.
>JBweld can fix almost anything
>If you see rust there is probably more.
>Rust and bodywork are by far the most difficult thing to repair.
>Electrical work is second most difficult, unless you stop reading forum posts and buy a multimeter.
>You're never actually going to finish that engine swap, stop pretending
>Do NOT buy a classic and plan to pay somebody to work on it. You need to be able to do 90% or greater of the work or you will go broke.
>You will inevitably spend twice your budget, unless you have years of experience under your belt. If all the salty old hands agree, it's probably true.
>No one cares about your MPG
>99% of boomers are cancer
>Nothing is as easy as it seems

What mostly fucked Kaiser was the pathetically weak flathead six under the hood. Nice looking bodies and expensive interiors meant nothing when it had 0-60 in 25 seconds acceleration, especially when you were paying nearly as much for the car as you would a Buick.

I should add that Kaiser was a pioneer in the gaudy jukebox interiors that would become a 50s hallmark. During the 40s, when most car interiors were utilitarian layouts in neutral colors, they were going all-out with chrome and pastels.

subject: Need advice on buying a good, cheap, used car? Look here!
name: Anonymous
text: If you live in the US, this chart is your best place to start looking. International posters outside the US may have region specific options not shown here!

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: Need advice on how to inspect or test drive a used car? Read this.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Where do i find a used car?

In the US:

-autotrader.com

-carsforsale.com

-criagslist

In Canada:

-kijiji.ca

Need a place to reference tons of different used models side by side?

-edmunds.com

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Want to learn how to fix a car yourself?

Buy the Hayne's or Chilton repair for your car!

Repair manuals will tell you how to do the job and what you need to get it done

Start with simple things like how to change the air filter or tires, or maybe changing your oil

If you are still interested, keep exploring!

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
Want a bike instead?

Motorcycles are dangerous. Some tips on making them less so:

Beginner's guide, courtesy of Amerifag:
http://motorcyclebeginnerguide.weebly.com/

Buying a motorcycle?
<<<< Read this and this: http://www.clarity.net/~adam/buying-bike.html

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
And finally:

Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
"1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars"

Nah dude, old mate is right, carbs fucking suck.

>let's get this incredibly complex carb, with multiple different jets for different RPM
>change tuning of one jet mildly affects the tuning of others so even if you get one right it will be wrong as soon as you start tuning another RPM range
>fuel turns into varnish inside them so you have to clean them all the time
>use more fuel for less power, bad atomisation
>good luck changing your exhaust because it will fuck the whole tune and you will burn a hole in the top of your piston.
>fuck around with choke every morning when it's cold, look like an idiot cranking your bike

Vs EFI
>starts easy
>automatically gets perfect fuel ratio over all RPM
>no upkeep
>better power and fuel economy
>99% of time will handle minor mods without retune
>any shithead 20 year old with a laptop can tune it by making some green squares red.

Basically your an idiot if you don't want EFI. I would kill for it on my bike desu. Enjoy getting cucked by your carbs while EFI is being an alpha

The only redeeming feature of carbs is being able to kill the bike while it's running, pin the throttle, wait a bit then start it again and make gunshot sounds when the unburnt fuel in the exhaust ignites

>>21381614
Nah mate rebuild and tune, sorry I'm actually tuning it rather than just going "duhhh da manual says 6 turns on da pilot, that is definitely still correct 30 years later"

Day 1 rebuild, reassemble bike, quick sanity check tuning is about right reving in position by ear. If not adjust.

Day 2
Ride, check for any flat spots
If yes disassemble bike, adjust jets controlling that range, reassemble
Ride to friends shop with 4 vacuum guages, balance.
Short ride again, flat spot check (odds are none unless my original tuning was fucked anyway).

Maybe your doing it in a day on some single with a non adjustable carb, I'm on an i4 and it's not a day process doing in right.

>>3538243
but if I don't understand the fundamentals of what settings to use Im just gonna be shooting on auto

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538244
So shoot on auto for a while.

It will take you about 15 minutes to learn the relationship between iso, aperture, and shutter speed. It's not rocket science.

For now you'll learn more by doing than you will be sitting on your arse reading about doing. Go the fuck outside and look at the world, get interested in the things you see and take loads of pictures of them. Your natural curiosity will bring you back to theory when the time is right.

If you spend all your time reading about stuff that you haven't developed the chops to realise yet you'll just get frustrated, turn into a gear faggot and never take pictures

name: Anonymous
text:
Go /p/ro:
• Please post images that are JPG format, smaller than 1 MB, and/or about 1000 pixels on the longest side.
• Expect to be judged harshly. Learn to deal with it.

Want:
• We come here for photos, so post yours as often as possible, even if "image unrelated" to your text.
• "Flickr/500px/Tumblr/Facebook/Portfolio" threads are for critique and networking
• Use "Recent Photos" threads if you are shy or only want to post a couple of photos.
• Shared raw files which we can collectively edit for discussion of post-processing techniques, are encouraged.
• Use the catalog to consolidate similar topics (photographic themes, images or technical gear threads)

Do Not Want:
• Go to >>>/r/ for specific Photoshop requests.
• Gear threads are discouraged, but identified as necessary. Many users simply hide these threads.

Moar?

subject: Portrait lighting
name: Anonymous
text:
I was talking to some pro photographer on IG and he mentioned that you don't need a black background to get portraits like this.
How does one shoot a pic like this (lit face, black background) without using a black backdrop?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538411
according to the malaysian japanese guy on youtube you can use bright lights, a high shutter speed, and some distance from the wall

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538413
link?
I'm guessing you'd need to use stobe/flash or something like that. I'm still not sure though.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538416
that is correct. the subject is closer to the light than the wall, which means the subject is more brightly lit. the shutter speed is set to expose the flashed subject

replies.text:
>>3538232
Looks like camera shake. VR can help but is not omnipotent. Mind how you hold the camera and use shorter exposure time.

Can you explain why you decided to use f14, 1/30, ISO 560? If you can not, use program, aperture or shutter priority instead of manual.

replies.text: Genuinely don't understand the appeal of Richardson's work. Someone spoonfeed me.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3537887
To me it's about subtraction. How do you make an appealing portrait while removing a large tool in the portrait photographers toolbox, that is, use of lighting. By removing that variable and making everything direct flash (one of the most unflattering styles (also I realize he doesn't use this exclusively, but he uses it a lot)), you now have to make sure everything else is on point, and that is where I think Terry shines.
Also boobs.

>>3537887
No bullshit in the photos. He photographs the person without distractions. I was always trying to photograph the person and felt shit like bokeh and weird backgrounds took away from the whole point of taking a picture of a person. This isn't a rare example but it summed up Steve-O's career pretty well.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3537887
On September 10, 2004, today’s greatest living photographer is going to show the world why he deserves the notorious moniker “God of Truth.” Terry Richardson, the irreverent New Yorker who changed photography forever, will be showing his most personal work in years at Deitch Projects.

For those select few not familiar with Richardson’s work, it is an inimitable combination of low and high art. It is harsh and scary, lewd and erotic, hilarious and beautiful, but, most importantly, it is loved and understood by everyone who sees it. New York street kids are taught to understand the monolithic beauty of a Japanese landscape while the Parisian intelligentsia are taught the intricate workings of getting high in Hollywood at seven in the morning. How can the most exclusionary European snobs understand the grit of America’s alleys? For the same reason the worst junkies alive can wrap their minds around Terry’s sensual portraits of celebrities. His photographs are the truth. There is no pretension, no premeditation, and no agenda. Terry Richardson lives his life as a fearless sensualist, and his camera is always in hand capturing every second of the journey. Everything is there, bare and untethered for all to see, and if you are happy to be alive you cannot resist these depictions of our magnificent world gone mad. We see top models in their kitchen making a coffee with awful shorts on. We see the rich and famous cropped so close their age spots look like delicate watercolors. It’s always real, and it’s always right. To put it simply, Richardson’s depictions of his day-to-day are the most sincere and genuine images of the twenty-first century.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538423
Fans of Terry’s work will be excited to hear that Richardson’s forthcoming Deitch show soars past all his previous work. It is his most heartfelt and endearing work to date, a relentless onslaught of everything that makes his photos beautiful, but with more passion and sincerity than ever before. Every person who sees this show will be forever altered because the “God of Truth” has surpassed himself and taken his relentlessly venerated genius to a new height of ecstasy. This is more than a tasteful art show about the beauty we all take for granted. It is the documentation of a miracle.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3537348
Probably not, historically they've excelled at medium format and they're basically the only choice in digital MF now after the 50R and GFX 100. They're one of the smallest camera manufacturers in terms of adoption rate and so if they started ANOTHER line of cameras and lenses to match they'd spread themselves too thin and most likely fail as a division. It's clever that they focus on what they excel at and leave the rest alone.

They're one of the only ones taking APS-C dead seriously making professional weather sealed bodies. Sony's A6*** are for poorfags and amateurs who don't know much about or need a truly professional body. So I'd say in their niche, they're better off being the best in APS-C and MF with laser focus instead of becoming a distant last in Full Frame too.

subject: /vid/ - Video General
name: Anonymous
text:
I'm back edition
All video related questions and discussion is intended for this thread. Here we discuss techniques, gear and anything else related to capturing video footage. Please don't pretend to be an expert if you don't know what you're talking about. Kindly leave your ego at the door.
Posting short films/scripts or other work you've done is encouraged.
We tend to use and recommend DSLRs/mirrorless cameras because they provide phenomenal picture quality for their price, have large sensors (ie the same size used in high-end cinema cameras and higher) and have interchangeable lenses.
In contrast, consumer camcorders normally have much smaller sensors and a fixed lens.

>STICKY - https://pastebin.com/ryMSvthn
>Helpful guide, additional books and more in-depth FAQs - https://pastebin.com/kG0gRmTZ

Previous thread >>3526380

Quick FAQS
>what’s the best camera available on a “budget”?
The blackmagic pocket cinema camera 4k, by a considerable margin
>>what’s a good beginner video camera?
Buy a used canon m50
>Can I use a zoom lens for video?
Yes
>Do I need cine lenses?
No
>Do I need 4k?
No. It will make your footage look sharper if it’s in focus, and it gives you breathing room in post. But 1080p is still absolutely fine
>Are camcorders okay?
Yes

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3529685
Try one out and see for yourself. It's pretty hard to describe and I guess what makes a camera "fun" is different for everyone.

If you want to basically LARP the film experience (manual exposure, physical dials, "film simulations", retro form factor/aesthetics) and go slow, you can.
If you want to use more automation, digital command dials to control your parameters etc. to go faster, you can.
If you want to switch between the two or do something in between, you can.
It's just a very well thought out camera concept that seems to be appealing to a lot of people. The retro dials immediately stand out, but what many people seem to forget is that underneath there's also an extremely solid, intuitive and configurable UI.

I also have experience with several Canon and Sony cameras, and while Fuji isn't "objectively" more "fun", it does have a very specific user experience. To me personally they're the most comfy to use, and also fun I guess, but I don't expect anyone else to share that opinion (dunno why a lot of folks here seem to get their jimmies rustled every single time this "fun" stuff is mentioned).

>>3529685
I've recently gotten an X-T3 and I love it. I was waiting on Nikon's mirrorless offering but then they dropped those two Zturds so I gave up on them. I had been shooting mostly film on my Nikon FTN or on my Nikon F4s for quite a while. It's hard to describe, but the dials on the X-T3 are really sweet, "fun" is a good word. It feels more like a machine than a computer, I don't know if that makes sense.

The other main issue is Canon/Nikon/Sony all treat their crop sensor line as just the cheapo shit. Fuji is dedicated APSC so you can take advantage of smaller but good lenses. On an even more extreme example, I have a bunch of lenses for the Nikon 1 mirrorless system they just killed, and I liked that in some situations, for a similar reason: you can make really small glass for that sensor. It's not as extreme in the Fuji APSC world, but it's still a bit of an advantage there. For a concrete example, I've got a 30-110 lens for the Nikon 1, and that's equivalent to a 80-300 in a full frame. But it's the same size of my 50mm prime for the Nikon F, which is insane. There are advantages and disadvantages to a smaller sensor size, but smaller glass is probably the main advantage.

>>3530124
>>3530193
Pros = wedding photographers that's true, but there's lots of other situations where pros will always go manual. If you have more than a half-second to get the shot, you should be tweaking it in manual. So landscape, product photography, architecture/real estate, all should be manual. And even a lot of the stereotypical wedding photographers will dial in for the room and shoot manual that way.

Long term I think that Fuji's refusal to do full frame and just keeping it split on a dedicated APSC and a medium format will pay off. In 10 years time, how much of a gap between the two will still exist in-between where full-frame makes sense, and you wouldn't want either the smaller lighter APSC, or the bigger sensor?

No, but I've used quite a few of Canon's full frame bodies.

Fujifilm's IQ is top notch. Their APS-C sensors go head to head with full frame and win. I love the build quality, image quality, weather sealing, lens selection, ergonomics, everything. The only disappointing aspect is battery life, but the X-H1 comes with 3 batteries so I can't complain too much.

As others have said, Fuji focusing on APS-C and medium format is great. APS-C is a very capable sensor size, yet every other company uses it to incentivize an upgrade to their full frame system. To the Fuji owners here that actually have one of those thousand-buttons&dials models:

The sony a6000 (and better) has a neat thing where you can set a bounded ISO/shutter speed/aperture, ie. other settings stay automatic or set to a specific amount, but ISO is allowed to semi-automatically shift between a lower and upper bound of 200 and 3200.

Similarly, and in conjunction to the ISO, you might also set a lower and upper bound for the shutterspeed, say between 1/25 and 1/100, using the generic spin-dial to achieve a user-desired effect of shifting the balance between less blur or less noise.

The fuji, as far as I've seen, have dedicated dials for shutter speed and ISO, with an optional "A" on said dials if one wishes for this setting to be automatic.

As such, is bounding even possible?

>>3536587
Transmission is how much light actually gets through, on a decent lens, like the sony 85mm f1.4 gm, the transmission is t1.5, barely less than the aperture. Aperture, f, is a physical ratio of the lens elements, transmission is the actual measured amount of light, in a perfect lens they would be identical.

>>3538271
Sharpness was never a problem for mft, in fact it's lenses are often so sharp it's posing problems. I was scratching myself silly when I bought my first mft cam and couldn't put my regular editing techniques on the images, then I figured that sharpening works reverse to what I was doing. You need slight 0.5-0.3 px adjustments, and copious amounts of general regional desharpening on the image, as opposed to regular deconvolution methods of ff sensors. I was only ever on 24mp/20mp on ff, and I eventually learned that going from very large pixel densities to very small ones, warrants different approaches.

>I don't need to. What part of it *specifically* do you think refuted the point that I made about the resolution of the eye.
Quoted from the article:
Visual Acuity and Resolving Detail on Prints

How many pixels are needed to match the resolution of the human eye? Each pixel must appear no larger than 0.3 arc-minute. Consider a 20 x 13.3-inch print viewed at 20 inches. The Print subtends an angle of 53 x 35.3 degrees, thus requiring 53*60/.3 = 10600 x 35*60/.3 = 7000 pixels, for a total of ~74 megapixels to show detail at the limits of human visual acuity.

The 10600 pixels over 20 inches corresponds to 530 pixels per inch, which would indeed appear very sharp. Note in a recent printer test I showed a 600 ppi print had more detail than a 300 ppi print on an HP1220C printer (1200x2400 print dots). I've conducted some blind tests where a viewer had to sort 4 photos (150, 300, 600 and 600 ppi prints). The two 600 ppi were printed at 1200x1200 and 1200x2400 dpi. So far all have gotten the correct order of highest to lowest ppi (includes people up to age 50). See: http://www.clarkvision.com/articles/printer-ppi

>In your own words, please.
In my own words? You're dead fucking wrong on what people can see at 5ft and 1.5ft. Hell, you don't even understand the terminology (visual acuity is measured in degrees of arc, not "mm in diameter" which is meaningless without a specified distance).

Now go do an 8k test like you promised.

All of the modern sources for deriving eye resolution that use arc minutes cite the number of 0.94 arc minutes. This is the number the military uses for visual acuity test formulations for pilots; In fact, they round up to .1 arc minute, which is roughly equivalent to .1mm at 10cm distance. If you actually did your fucking research and were capable of basic arithmetic, you'd have figured this out already.

Secondly, even if we accept his erroneous math, my examples STILL work out to being indistinguishable from higher resolution prints at a distance of 5 feet, which were my original stated conditions. Let's see if you can work out that math for the class.

>can you explain why ff is better *smugsmugsmug*

The fact this needs to be reiterated shows that you're a fucking newfag that doesn't know shit.

>crispness

Larger sensor = resolves more fine detail, if you have a ff and mft sensor, both with equal mp count, the centre to centre distance of pixel sites is twice as far away on ff, meaning to resolve the exact same amount of detail across the surface of the sensor mft would need glass that resolves 4 times as much detail.

Now you've got 2 options, admit ff will always have crisper details due to the higher resolution AND sharpness of ff. OR double down and claim mft lens makers have access to super special glass that's 4 times as good as anyone else can get...

>3d pop

Bigger sensor = longer fl = smoother bokeh, better subject isolation and better perspective. Go look at some large format photos, you see that pop, that's entirely due to having a larger sensor and longer lens.

Thanks for admitting you don't know the absolute basics of optics ya fucking mong.

replies.name: Anonymous

>>3534686
The Fujifilm battery grip is really good, I use mine on my X-T2. It gives two extra batteries plus the one inside the camera to a total of three. It also unlocks a more powerful boost mode to speed up some functions of the camera. Three batteries lasts me all day even as I heavily photograph and record video.

Other than a battery grip just buy batteries in bulk and keep a few in your pocket. It only takes a second to swap them out. Make sure you have a system where you know which ones are empty and which are charged. I put my empty ones upside down in a case and the charged ones with brand facing up.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3534787
Buying a film scanner will save you money long-term, not cost you more. If you're paying a lab to scan all your negatives for you, that typically costs a ton of cash. Multiply it by how many rolls you finish a year and you have way more than a Plustek scanner will cost you.

If you're not invested in film enough to justify a scanner, which says to me you barely clear one roll a month if that and so don't see the cost saving benefits, then yes maybe you'd be better going digital. It's all subjective to your situation and if you're into film as a hipster fad or genuinely love it.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3535527
I'm also not a fan of being a stupid consumerist buying the latest and greatest. Is there anything I should know about buying used cameras?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3535528
Try to aim for prosumer models, generally the entry level cameras get tech from older prosumer models but also gimped features, so even if the camera is older, chances are it's better than gimped entry shit and often priced the same.

Lenses matter more than the camera body, so adjust budget ratio accordingly. Ask yourself what sort of focal length (and physical size of lens) you're comfortable with then research bodies

Keep in mind that cameras have a finite lifespan , mainly dictated by the amount of actuations of the shutter. Generally these are rated at 100k clicks or more.

I'd feel perfectly comfortable with 30-50k done on my camera, depending on physical condition otherwise. 30k is not little and the camera was used plenty so it may have seen some shit in its life

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3536239
if you want ultra-super-maximum resolution and you have a static subject that will sit still while you photograph it, then you can take a bunch of exposures and stitch them together to make a ginormous, 200+-megapixel image. Any recent camera can do this, the main thing you need is a tripod. If you want a really extra-sharp lens just buy a 50mm for whatever system you decide you prefer and shoot it at f/5.6 or f/8, any 50 will be razor-sharp across the APS-C frame at that aperture. More important than the gear is a steady camera and precise focus. Shoot raw (duh) and keep the ISO down and use a longer exposure if you can to reduce noise, since noise reduction smudges fine detail.

if you really care about corner sharpness, probably a used a6000 plus sigma 16 1.4 dc dn (if you want an AF wide lens). the 16mm isn't macro but has a min. focus distance of 10 inches or 25 cm. shoot with the appropriate aperture for max sharpness, also shoot raw then open in LR to apply distortion correction profile, use the sharpness and clarity slider to make the image look sharper. another lens is sigma 30 1.4 dc dn, general focal length but just a bit less sharper than the 16mm. do you have access to any camera even with a kit lens? to know what specific focal length you need.

Okay here's my review of the X-T2.

Pros:
Weather sealing works great, taken it out in the rain and snow a few times and never had an issue

Feels solid and the materials feel premium
Grippy all over instead of the slippery glossy plastic often used by the competition

The UI is really intuitive and the Q menu is a lifesaver

The RAF files are some of the easiest I've worked with in Capture One

EXTREMELY customisable, I turned off the top dials and use the back and front dial to control iso/shutter speed/exposure comp. The competition only lets you assign a few C1 buttons in comparison.

EVF is extremely responsive, especially in boost mode. I really feel the difference going back to earlier mirrorless cameras. 100fps makes a big improvement.

SILENT/ELECTRONIC shutter, my god this is the main reason I changed to Fuji. The Sony shutter is louder than most of my film cameras. https://youtu.be/-qAF4yFqOdw

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>3538235
Cons:
I often knock the lower dials around, like sometimes I take the camera out of my bag and it has moved from single shot to multiple exposure. Or from matrix metering to spot. It would be nice if I could lock them like the rest of the dials with locks.

My pinky falls off the grip and it feels better with a battery grip. I had the exact same issue with the A6000 but to a worse degree. Both cameras are a hair too small.

Lens hoods have sucked.

Back button focusing is shit on Fuji, I actually prefer the back button focus on the A6000. I get by fine on Fuji but it isn't as comfortable where your thumb is always close by.

The battery grip sometimes loses connection to the camera so I have to wiggle it a bit to restart it. I think they fixed that in the X-T3.

There's no flip out screen or touch screen, not a deal breaker but people sometimes expect one when I lend them my camera.

Some options are buried really deeply in the menus to my taste, like when you want to access the second layer of film simulations/effects it's sometimes a hassle. I prefer simplicity above anything else.

Autofocus is great but not quite as snappy as the A6000. I'd say they're about 5% apart depending on the lens, like the 27mm f2.8 performs a bit worse than my 35mm f2.

Anyway that's really it for me. I need to take my GW690 out tonight so cheers for the shitposting.

>>478644832
I don't know why but I've been getting bluescreens again and mostly when I emulate stuff but I don't know what exactly is causing it but I think it might be due to Vulkan that's my current suspicion anyway. Vulkan is great and all but for instance when I fuck around with shaders in Retroarch using Vulkan I get bluescreens pretty regularly, that's my most repeatable example, I can pretty much induce a bluescreen by just loading a couple shader presets back to back. Solution: don't fuck around with shaders in Retroarch pretty much solved it. But today I was playing PPSSPP and when I hit alt+enter to full screen it after a couple hours of playing windowed it bluescreened me which came as a shock because I remember PPSSPP being pretty damn stable but then again this time I was using the Vulkan API. It also happened with Dolphin once but in that case I was almost trying to make it crash because I was trying to take pictures at 8x native resolution with 8xSSAA and I just checked my API and of course it too was Vulkan, but still Dolphin has been rocksolid for years and years and I'm at the point of thinking nothing should ever give me a BSOD but recently I've been getting hit with them. I haven't been getting BSODs on anything else, normal PC games are usually pretty solid but in those cases most PC games still use DX11 and as of yet all the things that have Bluescreened on me it seems the common link is pushing Vulkan to it's limits and having it crash.

Anyone else getting BSODs? Is is Vulkan or do I have something else going on?

Resident Evil for the original Playstation. I was too scared to play it at night if I was by myself. But I was 11 when it came out.

Then Blood because it had creepy level and enemies. Plus it was super hard.

Then Silent Hill 2.

Then Amnesia: The Dark Descent.

Then first half of The Evil Within.

Then SOMA.

Now I'm 34 and want more than anything to be able to be creeped out and scared by movies or vidya again like when I was young.

I dreamed I was old.

1. go to isthereanydeal.com

3. filter by "Giveaway"

Keep in mind, though, that the free giveaways you see on Steam are organized by the publishers of individual games, not by Steam itself. The purpose of Epic's giveaways is to expand the userbase; Steam doesn't need to do that. So games are free on Steam only when those games' publishers decide to do it, usually to promote a sequel or some other new game they're releasing.

>>478649961
The idea is Epic gets people who aren't attached to Steam, primarily kids who mostly just play Fortnite, to develop an attachment to the EGS by filling their library, so they'll buy from the EGS instead of using multiple launchers.
I've seen plenty of people on /v/ complain about Steam only to say they're in too deep to stop using it because they'd lose all their games. Epic is trying to cultivate that for the new generation.
That being said I haven't spent a cent on the EGS and only poach free games and play Fortnite and I imagine most kids who play an F2P game won't be spending a lot of money buying games, so whether this works long-term is to be seen. I don't think Epic can keep up their "buy exclusives and pay devs to give away their games" strategy forever; Tencent could fund this shit indefinitely with how massive they are but at some point they'll probably pull the plug if some major profits don't happen.

Reminder that the EGS still doesn't have a shopping cart.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>478657346
She's not, she's flawed. Every lord is majorly flawed.

Edelgard has tunnel vision due to being experimented on and having her life shortened mixed with a strong sense of patriotism to the Empire. She does so much shit because, to her, the world NEEDS to change and she won't live long enough to do it the calm way. She's also functionally held prisoner by Dubsteppers in part 1 because they can just have her killed and replaced if she doesn't play along, plus her uncle is on their side.

Dimitri has so much rage and anger boiling inside him since the death of his father and the treatment of the Duscar mixed with a religious kingdom, a love for combat and Edlegard-autism that once it all snaps, he does too and becomes a man with nothing to live for besides violently lashing out against everyone who hurt him, sort of like a wounded animal, possibly one with tusks. Those flames are fanned in the war making him think he's the ONLY one who can stop Edelgard because he gave her a dagger to tell her he loved her once.

Claude is removed from most of Fodlan and is too much of a coward to really confront his problems, so he tries to scheme and deflect around them. His inaction means that he can't stand up to aggressors when the time is right and its only with Byleth that his efforts are focused anywhere useful.

And Rhea is an immortal demigod who watched her mother killed and siblings turned into weapons, something that drove her so far off the deep end that she had to fake her own death and assume another identity that she used to manipulate an entire continent for a thousand years through the church with the singular focus of getting back what she lost, because she never got over her trauma until Byleth/Sothis came back.

None of the route main characters are remotely good people and every one of them is guilty of extreme arrogance. Arguing over "who's the worst though" is juvenile.

replies.text:
I've said it before, and I will say it again, Edelgard is a bad person and is written as such. It is ironically at its clearest in Black Eagles, where you spend the most time around Hubert and her. When it isn't Byleth's life being threatened, it's backroom talks amounting to "How can we make them useful to us?". Edelgard herself acknowledges she is a horrible creature, and has more respect for you in the routes where you tell her to fuck off rather than giving in to your carnal desire to ejaculate in her hair. If you give in to her, she sees you like her favorite toy, leaving you high and dry once you're no longer useful to her, coming back to you only once she's decrepit.

Everything about her is manipulative, diseased. Dimitri is there to show people what happens when you try to reach out to her, or worse, submit. People keep trying to meme her as a failed Arvis with tits, but that was never the point of her character in the first place. Redemption or remorse aren't in her vocabulary, she's a sociopath that has to be put down. The only reason her route turns out good is because of Byleth's divine interference, and he ends up the worst off in a world where his very existence is banned.

There is only one very obvious angle to liking her.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
To start, I want to make a point about what Edelgard's route is really about. It is, more than any other route, about the relationship between the main lord and Byleth as characters. Obviously, there are huge thematic parallels running between Edelgard and Byleth that make them come into conflict on all other routes. Both Edelgard and Byleth were implanted with the Crest of Flames by an ancient organization. These organizations did this out of the desire to either literally or metaphorically recreate a figure from the ancient past-Nemesis in Edelgard's case and Sothis in Byleth's. Neither of these organizations really cared about or considered Byleth or Edelgard as individual people, they were just vessels to bring back the past. The consequences for both characters were immense.

Byleth literally does not have a heartbeat, and has a reduced ability to feel emotion. They grew up with Jeralt and no other friends or companions, and Jeralt, while a lovely man, is not the type to foster emotional sensitivity and growth. They work as a mercenary referred to as a "demon" who would remorselessly cut down his/her enemies. Jeralt gives orders and Byleth follows, and he/she is very much alone in the world.

Edelgard's crest implementation did not magically remove her emotions-but the incredible trauma of losing her siblings, losing her lifespan, living in chronic pain, and her PTSD may as well have. Her only meaningful relationship is Hubert, who follows her mainly due to her status as Imperial Princess, and like Byleth, no one looks at her as a person- just a weapon or a head of state. Edelgard, out of the desire to insure that no one ever has to suffer like her siblings and her did, subsumes her actual personality into the persona of the Flame Emperor, and plans to change the world by any means necessary.

replies.name: Anonymous

>>478661089
When Byleth sides with her in the tomb, for the first time, Byleth is making a decision that is Byleth's own, and not what Rhea or Jeralt or Seteth tell him to do. Isn't it interesting that a prominent heartbeat sound is heard when Byleth makes the choice to defend Edelgard or side with Rhea? Rhea is (understandably) angry, and it is the fact that he is a unique person, not a blank vessel for Sothis, that makes him a "failure". Meanwhile, Edelgard realizes that someone believes in and values her as a person. Byleth's moment of individual belief allows Edelgard to just be herself-"Just Edelgard"- and over the 5 year time skip she tries to live up to Byleth's example by keeping TWSITD on a leash, and fight her war as honorably as possible, even though her reduced lifespan has made her desperate. Post time-skip in Edelgard's route when she is around Byleth, you see glimpses of the actual person hiding behind the mask of the Flame Emperor- a dorky, sweet, lonely girl who does awful impressions of Hubert and draws pictures of her crush. The person the lyrics of Edge of Dawn are sung by and about. However, even when putting down childhood friend Dimitri, you see a person afraid of and unwilling to express their emotions- "The Edelgard who cries died years ago."

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text:
>>478661089
So, the ending. Look at Edelgard's character growth! After poor Rhea demands Byleth's heart back (still not viewing Byleth as a person), she says "if humanity stands strong, and people reach out for each other, there's no need for gods." Does this sound like the person who plotted and schemed and was unable to confide in Byleth in Part 1? Edelgard and Byleth, two individuals defined by how they are "seperated from the ordinary world", then use teamwork and trust in each other to defeat Rhea. Now-look at the body language and role Byleth plays in all other route endings. Byleth is there to provide Dimitri emotional support, pick up Claude, and cradle Rhea. Byleth is valuable to these characters, but ultimately he/she is the "Enlightened One" who supports their goals and makes them possible. Here, it is Edelgard who physically supports Byleth. The relationship between them is one of mutual support, where Edelgard allowed Byleth to express his/her individuality for the first time, and Byleth's trust allows Edelgard to be vulnerable and express her best qualities.

And that relationship of mutual trust and love between two people with a "heart of ice" is rewarded- Byleth's humanity is restored as his/her heart begins to beat for the first time (the only route where this happens), while the Edelgard who supposedly "died years ago" finally returns, and her own heart and emotions are restored as she openly cries. And in their paired ending, Byleth's title isn't the Enlightened One- it's Wings of Hegemon, neatly paralleling how the Blue Lions final boss is called Hegemon Edelgard, and showing how Byleth lifted Edelgard out of the darkness.

TL:DR All your other ships are garbage, Edelgard X Byleth forever
